captions.text: Ramen in Poland it's mostly known from 'Ichiraku Ramen'
the favourite lunch spot of Naruto,
a character in anime series named, somewhat similarly, 'Naruto'.
But ramen is more than that - it's one of the best meals you could eat in Japan
an wonderful dish, with a superb, complex flavour.
Let us show you what it's all about.
This is miso ramen
you've got all those extra toppings here
eggs and whatnot. You can buy beer as well.
I'm going for a regular set with gyoza, local dumplings
you can take your ticket and go grab a seat.
In this ramen place you can specify exactly what kind of ramen you want
play around with the controls, so to speak.
You can choose how soft you want your noodles cooked,
I want mine a bit harder.
Sauce - I'll have it stronger,
Oili...ness? There's even an option aptly translated to English as 'too much'.
Let's have it medium oily.
Do we want - I think that's leek?
We do want leek.
How spicy? I like it spicy, let's go for... level 3
And... pork, yes, of course we want pork.
Now we need to pick 4 toppings from this list
I like egg best, I like the way it's served in ramen.
Good stuff.
What else?
'The cloudear', 'the sungan' - some local obscurities
I'm going for kimchi
It's not Japanese, but I like it a lot.
Let's have some seaweed as well, my bet is it's going to be nori
...and we'll also take 'the cloudear', whatever it might be.
After filling in the form we can pass it on to the staff
and they'll prepare our ramen.
The whole idea is to minimize the time they have to spend dealing with customer service,
so first you order it via vending machine,
and here you have condiments to last you a lifetime.
Grab your chopsticks,
pour yourself some water,
some pickled ginger, sauces, relishes.
Napkins.
Everything you could possibly need.
Smells crazy good.
In Japan ramen is super popular, perhaps the most popular type of meal.
It might sound odd, in Poland we mostly associate Japan with sushi
but the reality is, our Japanese friends are much, much fonder of ramen,
and they won't shut up about it.
Ramen is a common thing to have at work, on your lunch break
a popular choice for dinner as well,
and what's interesting, ramen is strongly tied to Japanese drinking culture.
It'd be your usual food of choice before or after you go drinking
or even while you're out - for the extra strength needed to combat the booze.
This is spicy, Korean red chilli paste, called gochujang,
ubiquitous in Korean cuisine.
This must be 'the cloudear'
there's kimchi - looks kinda weird, but it's kimchi
there's some onion as well, and what was translated to English as 'seaweed'
turned out to be garlic flakes.
We have chopsticks and a spoon,
the usual way to do it is to hold the chopsticks in your dominant hand,
spoon in the other, and to alternate between the two.
Naturally, as it's often the case in Japan
there is a set of rules, but everybody eats their food whichever way they please.
You use chopsticks to grab the toppings, and spoon for the soup, obviously.
When you eat ramen - you slurp.
It's not like there's a special etiquette requiring you to slurp
the reason is quite prosaic - ramen is usually served piping hot.
And you don't want to burn yourself with those noodles
but at the same time you sure as hell are not waiting for it to cool down.
Slurping is the answer.
Even as you slurp you can see it steaming.
If I were to eat it just like that, I'd definitely burn myself.
Slurping makes it cool down, so this way
noodles are no longer a threat.
I'm going to have some gyoza as well.
Just as Marcin said, it's surprisingly similar to Polish pierogi.
The crucial ingredient in ramen is liquid,
the noodles are the thing to geek out about in your ramen.
There are many different kinds, in Tokyo it's usually thin noodles
they remind me of soba, although apparently they're not the same thing.
Which leads us to the conclusion, that saying 'I've tried ramen'
is like saying 'I had a pizza once'.
I mean the types of ramen, flavours, toppings, all the different variations
are countless.
Which brings about the classification
for example you have basic kinds of ramen, such us shio - the savoury one
miso - which is miso-based, soy ramen
and the absolute cult classic with our friends here - tonkotsu ramen
thick, bright in colour, made by boiling pork bones.
So good, definitely my favourite.
There's an entire blog scene devoted to ramen here!
There's even ramen tourism. People go travelling to different places in Japan
- well, maybe ramen's not their only reason -
but checking out local types of ramen is definitely something you'd be expected to do as a tourist.
Right, when we're finished with the toppings, and all that's left is noodles,
we can go ahead - it's actually sort of encouraged here -
and just drink it up like this.
As you see the topic is vast,
but in the end it all boils down to the fact,
that this stuff's amazingly delicious.
The options are diverse, and the price range affordable.
Ramen dishes start at 500 yen and they go up to about 1,000.
Sometimes even more, but anything over a 1,000 yen
would have to be some sort of ridiculous designer ramen, or... just a really, really big serving.
So if you're here - you simply have to check out some ramen
I'd say - try at least two different types
because that's where the real fun starts,
when you realize how many possibilities are there,
and what surprises to be found.

title: Ramen - największy przysmak w Japonii? [Tokio] // The name of the game is Ramen [Eng Subs]

comments.text:
Najbardziej wkurwiający są Polacy-Cebulacy, którzy w avatarach mają anime, 
imiona po japońsku i nazywają siebie otaku. Najbardziej pojebani ludzie na 
świecie! ﻿
comments.author: Artur Bilik

comments.text:
+Artur Bilik zgadzam się z Tobą, otaku, hahahahhaha, banda gimbusów i 
niedouczonych licealistów, marzących, że kiedyś wyjadą z tej "zacofanej, 
biednej polski przez małe p" i osiądą niczym bogowie w idealnej Japonii. 
Każdy marzy o nauce japońskiego, chce studiować orient i japonistykę, a 
później kończy jak córka mojego kolegi z pracy (ona-rocznik 1995), pracując 
na kasie w Kauflandzie. Oczywiście w liceum, wyciągała grubą kasę od 
rodziców na naukę japońskiego, a cały pokój ma w mangach i płytach z muzyką 
z kraju przekwitłej wiśni. Plus ciuchy, fryzury i cały image rodem z 
anime/mangi. Ogólnie mam wiele współczucia dla tych młodych i głupich, mają 
po 13-19 lat i wydaje im się, że Japonia na nich czeka. Jasne warto mieć 
marzenia, ale trzeba być i realistą, zasada pt "jak chcesz to możesz być 
każdym" rzadko się sprawdza, to bujda na resorach. Tacy co kochają Japonię, 
chcą tam żyć i udaje im się to, są takim promilem, że nie warto o tym 
mówić. Marzyć można, ale trzeba dorosnąć i zagospodarować sobie życie, a 
nie siedzieć na garnuszku rodziców, z nosem w necie i snuć bujdy o tym jak 
"za kilka lat zbiore pieniążki, postudiuję troszkę japonistykę, na 
wyższej-niższej-szkole-zarządzania-marketingu i opierdalania i POJADĘ DO 
JAPONII JAAAAAAAJ, ale fajnieeee, ale fajnie!!!!. I oczywiście jestem 
otaku" takim syfem lodówki sobie nie napełnicie otakowe dzieciaczki, ani 
nie zapłacicie rachunków za internet, bez którego, nawet tej Japonii nie 
poliżecie przez ekran lapka.
comments.author: Miki Mihuro

niż leworęcznych ze względu chociażby na to iż jest to bardziej pospolite. 
Fakty z Bravo zachowaj dla siebie.

wogule znalezc tu swine to ciezka sprawa jest ich pelno ale nie jadalnych 
pomimo ze maja tez male skosne oczka jak mi sie uda znalezc ta jadalna to 
 jak ja zlapie to osobiscie wypatrosze i przerobie na smakowite szyneczki 
bo juz mam k....a dosyc tego ryzu i beznadziejnej zupy ramen :((( ja chce

potraw !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! nie ma sie co zbytnio zachwycac 
tym japonskim menu :(
